content.Title: Improved UX and Security: Switching to Time-based One Time Passwords (TOTPs)!
content.Body:
[![totp](https://github.com/epicweb-dev/epic-stack/assets/1500684/f8ace33c-3136-478c-8441-a53ac95101c4)](https://www.epicweb.dev/tips/improve-ux-and-security-with-time-based-one-time-passwords-totps)

[Watch Kent's rundown and demo here](https://www.epicweb.dev/tips/improve-ux-and-security-with-time-based-one-time-passwords-totps): https://www.epicweb.dev/tips/improve-ux-and-security-with-time-based-one-time-passwords-totps

- https://github.com/epicweb-dev/epic-stack/blob/main/docs/decisions/013-email-code.md

Conversation.Prompt:
I'm building an authentication workflow that involves sending an email with a magic link to verify the user's email. I want to avoid doing anything in the database regarding the magic link. So I encrypt a payload (includes the email it's intended for and it doesn't include an expiration currently, but it certainly could) and include that encrypted token in the email as a query parameter on the magic link. However, I just realized that I was hard-coding the salt which reduces the level of security and opens me up to brute force attacks.

I'd still like to avoid touching the database for this, so I don't want to have to generate the salt and put it in the database. I considered putting the generated salt in the magic link query string as well. I realize this reduces the security a bit, but I'm wondering whether in a practical scenario if it's really that big of an issue and if I can address any holes that opens me up to.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this. Feel free to make a completely different suggestion I may not have considered or tell me that I really should just write something to the database for this process.

I have also considered putting the salt in the user's session.

I'm also adding a feature that allows the user to enter 5 random numbers into the app instead of clicking a link. Those numbers will be encrypted using the same method and that encrypted value will be stored in a cookie.

Hopefully that's enough context for you to make a recommendation on what I should do about the salt.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCreating secure authentication workflows can be a tricky business, but it's great that you're giving this a lot of thought. Here are some options you might consider:Use a dynamic, non-secret value as a salt: Instead of hard-coding the salt or including it in the link, you could derive it from some other value that you're already sending. For example, you could use a hashed version of the user's email as the salt. This would provide unique salts for each user without you having to store them anywhere. However, since the email address itself isn't secret, this wouldn't necessarily add a lot of security - it would primarily serve to thwart precomputed dictionary attacks ("rainbow tables").Include the salt in the link: While you're right that this reduces security somewhat, it might be a reasonable compromise given your requirements. A potential attacker would still need to break your encryption in order to use the link, and if your encryption is strong, this should be difficult. To make the links safer, consider using a secure random generator to produce the salt.Store the salt in a user session: This could work, but user sessions typically live on the server, so this would contradict your requirement of not touching the database (unless you're using a stateless JWT-style session, in which case you're back to sending the salt to the client).JWT tokens: You could use JSON Web Tokens (JWT) to create the magic links. JWTs are a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. You can include the user's email and an expiration time in the token, then sign it using a secret key. When the user clicks the link, you validate the token and, if it's valid and not expired, the email is verified. You don't need to store anything in the database, and there's no need for a salt because you're not hashing anything. The downside is that if an attacker gets your secret key, they can create valid tokens.TOTP for random numbers: If you're asking users to enter random numbers, consider using Time-based One-Time Password (TOTP) algorithm. It generates a one-time password based on the current time and a secret key. The server knows the secret key and can generate its own OTPs to compare with what the user entered. The nice thing about TOTP is that it automatically includes expiration (because the OTP changes over time), and if you only accept each OTP once, it can't be reused even if it's intercepted.In general, make sure to use secure, up-to-date cryptographic algorithms and libraries. Older algorithms and libraries may have known vulnerabilities that make your system easier to attack. Consider also rate limiting attempts to use the magic link to mitigate brute force attacks.

Conversation.Prompt:
Thanks. A few follow-ups:

- For option 1, I hadn't considered this. Thwarting precomputed dictionary attacks is my primary objective, because it's the main vulnerability I'm trying to fix. Are there other vulnerabilities I should be concerned about? This option doesn't seem any more complicated to implement or maintain than option 2 and that feels safer. Is it?
- For option 2, I think I prefer this option. Are there other considerations I should keep in mind?
- For option 3, I could avoid writing to the database if I put the value of the salt in a cookie. The attacker would still have access to it if they submitted it themselves, but they wouldn't have access to the salt if they hacked into people's emails. However, this has the drawback of the user being unable to sign in from a different browser from the one that requested the token which I've already experienced in another app as something people complain about. So is the concern about someone hacking into people's emails all that valid in a practical scenario?
- For option 4, Wouldn't another downside of the JWT token approach be that it is vulnerable to rainbow tables as well?
- This sounds like a pretty good solution. Would it be reasonable to use a TOTP both as something I display for people to type as well as a query param in the magic link? Are TOTPs too long to expect a user to type? Keep in mind they may not be able to copy/paste because they may be using a different device to look at the email from the one they're typing into.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTOption 1: This is a simple and effective approach for thwarting precomputed dictionary attacks, but keep in mind it is only as secure as the hash function you use. Since the salt isn't secret, a potential attacker could still make an offline attack if they get hold of your hashed data and know your algorithm. However, if you're using a strong encryption algorithm and a sufficiently complex key, this should be difficult.Option 2: There's not much difference in terms of security between options 1 and 2, but option 2 may be a bit simpler to implement. The main consideration here is that the salt should be randomly generated and sufficiently long to make guessing it impractical. Also, you should make sure that the generated links are only valid for a limited period of time to prevent their reuse if they are intercepted or leaked.Option 3: Putting the salt in a cookie would mean that it is tied to a specific browser, which could be inconvenient for users as you've noted. The risk of someone hacking into people's emails varies depending on the sensitivity of the data your app is handling. For most consumer applications, it's probably not a high risk, but it's not nonexistent either. If you're dealing with highly sensitive data, you might want to consider a more secure approach.Option 4: JWT tokens are signed but not encrypted by default, meaning the payload data can be read by anyone who intercepts the token. If an attacker has the secret key, they can forge tokens, which would be a problem. The key here is to keep the secret key secure. As for rainbow table attacks, they're more applicable to hashed values (like password hashes), not signed tokens like JWT. As long as you use a strong, secure secret key, rainbow attacks aren't really a concern for JWTs.Option 5: TOTP is a good solution, especially because it naturally prevents reuse of the code. However, typical TOTP codes are 6 digits long, which might be a bit long for users to type without errors. It could work in the query param for a magic link, but again, you would need to ensure that the magic link is used within a limited time frame. In practice, many services send TOTP codes via SMS or through an authenticator app. Remember, TOTP requires a shared secret between the server and the client. This secret must be securely stored and kept confidential, which might present its own challenges.Remember, security is all about trade-offs. Consider the sensitivity of the data you're protecting and the risks associated with different methods, and choose the method that provides an appropriate level of security for your specific situation.

Conversation.Prompt: Thanks. Please tell me more about TOTP solutions in a typical Node.js server setting.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTSure! There are a number of good libraries for implementing TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password) in Node.js. The most commonly used one is probably speakeasy.Here's a simple example of how you might use it:First, install the library with npm:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, you can generate a secret for a user:[CODE_BLOCK_1]When it's time to authenticate the user, you can generate a token and check it against the user's input:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Remember that TOTP tokens are only valid for a short period of time (usually 30 seconds). So if the time on your server is significantly different from the time on your user's device, verification might fail. If you're running into problems, you might want to consider using a NTP (Network Time Protocol) library to synchronize your server's time.To use this in a real-world scenario, you would need to securely store each user's secret (ideally in a hashed form), generate a token when the user initiates an authentication request, and verify the token when the user submits it.For added security, you might want to consider using a library like authenticator to generate QR codes that users can scan with an app like Google Authenticator. This would save them having to manually type in their secret.As always, remember that security is a complex field and there are many factors to consider when implementing any form of authentication. It's a good idea to do a thorough review of your system, possibly with the help of a security expert, before deploying it.

Conversation.Prompt: How hard would it be to implement TOPT without dependencies?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTImplementing TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password) from scratch without using existing libraries is possible, but it's a non-trivial task. The TOTP algorithm is defined in RFC 6238, and involves a number of cryptographic operations, including HMAC-SHA1 hashing and Base32 encoding.Here's a rough outline of the steps you would need to follow:Generate a Secret Key: This will be a random binary string, typically 80 bits or longer. You could generate it using a cryptographically secure random number generator.Share the Secret Key: You need to securely share this secret key with the user. Often this is done by creating a QR code that the user can scan using an authenticator app.Generate the TOTP: This involves several steps:Calculate the number of time steps between an epoch (usually 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC) and the current time. The time step is typically 30 seconds.Convert this time step value to a byte array.Calculate the HMAC-SHA1 hash of this byte array, using the secret key.Perform some operations on this hash to convert it into a 6-digit number.Validate the TOTP: When the user provides a TOTP, you need to repeat the generation process and see if you get the same result.There are a number of complexities here, including handling time synchronization issues, ensuring all your cryptographic operations are secure, and dealing with different encodings and data types. Implementing these yourself can be error-prone and is generally not recommended unless you have a very good reason for doing so.If you're concerned about dependencies, one option could be to use a smaller, more focused library that only handles the HMAC-SHA1 and Base32 encoding parts, and implement the TOTP-specific parts yourself. But in general, using a well-maintained and widely-used library like speakeasy is going to be both safer and easier.

Conversation.Prompt: To be clear, I'm fine using built-in Node.js libraries like the crypto module. Is this still pretty challenging?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTUsing built-in Node.js libraries like crypto does make implementing TOTP easier, but it's still a bit involved. Here's a rough outline of how you might implement TOTP using Node.js's built-in libraries:Generate a Secret Key: You can use the crypto.randomBytes function to generate a secure random key.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Generate the TOTP: This is where most of the complexity lies. The process includes:Getting the current Unix time and dividing it by the time step (typically 30 seconds).Converting this value to a buffer.Generating an HMAC-SHA1 hash of this buffer, using the secret key.Converting this hash into a 6-digit number.Here's how you might do it:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Validate the TOTP: You would use the same function to generate the TOTP when the user provides their code. Compare the provided code with the generated code. If they match, the code is valid.Keep in mind that this is a very simplified version of a TOTP generator and might not work correctly in all situations. It also doesn't handle error conditions, time synchronization issues, etc. If you decide to implement TOTP this way, you should thoroughly test your implementation and possibly have it reviewed by a security expert.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTSure, I can help you with that. We're going to use the notp package for the TOTP generation and verification and crypto for creating a secret key.Here's a simple module that handles these tasks:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this simple setup, nothing needs to be stored in a database. When you generate an OTP, you would email it to the user, and then when the user provides an OTP for verification, you would call verifyOTP(). If it returns a truthy value, the OTP is valid; otherwise, it's not.However, note that for this to be secure in a real system, each user should have a unique secret key, and you should securely store these keys. Here, we're using the same key for all users, which is not secure.As for environment variables, this setup doesn't require any. However, if you were storing the secret key(s) in an environment variable or a database, you would need to handle that.Please keep in mind that security is a complex field and there may be other considerations and potential vulnerabilities depending on the specifics of your system and use case. Conversation.Prompt:
> Here, we're using the same key for all users, which is not secure.

Could you elaborate on this point? I would like to avoid creating a table for this if possible. So I was thinking of generating a random key and setting that as an environment variable which every one of these uses. Why would that be a problem with this?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTUsing the same secret key for all users could pose a security risk. Here's why:The secret key is essentially the seed for the one-time password generation. If you're using the same secret key for all users, then the OTP generated at any given time will be the same for all users. This means that if an attacker manages to intercept or otherwise acquire a valid OTP, they could potentially use it to impersonate any user.Additionally, if the shared secret key were to be compromised (e.g., if an attacker gained access to your environment variables), they would be able to generate valid OTPs for any user. In contrast, if each user has a unique secret key, an attacker who compromises one key would only be able to impersonate that one user.That said, there may be scenarios where a shared key might be acceptable, depending on the specifics of your application and threat model. For example, if you're generating OTPs that are only used once and then immediately expired, and you have other layers of security in place, it might be less of a risk.However, it's generally considered best practice to use unique keys for each user to minimize the potential impact of a key being compromised.If you're looking to avoid creating a database table, one possibility might be to derive a unique secret key for each user based on some other unique attribute of the user (like their user ID or email), combined with a master key stored as an environment variable. But this has its own potential issues (for instance, you would need to handle key derivation securely), and in general it's still advisable to store per-user secret keys in a secure manner, which typically means a dedicated database table.

Conversation.Prompt:
Taking our entire conversation into context, I'm beginning to think it's best to create a database table for doing email verification and always ensuring there is a generated and persisted key for any operation like this.

If I were to change my preference of avoiding using the database to store the key, what would you recommend I do for email verification during onboarding assuming I want to keep the user experience of a magic link option as well as a short 5-6 digit number verification option.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTGiven that you're open to using a database and want to maintain both the magic link and short code verification options, here's a proposed solution:Create a Database Table: You will need a table to store the secret keys for each user, along with the generated OTP, timestamp of OTP generation, and user's email. You might name it email_verification.On User Registration: During user registration or when the user asks for a magic link/OTP:Generate a random secret key for the user using a cryptographically secure random number generator. Store this in the email_verification table along with the user's email.Generate the OTP using TOTP methodology and the user's secret key. Store the OTP and the generation time in the email_verification table.Send the OTP to the user's email as part of a magic link or a separate code.On User Verification: When the user clicks on the magic link or enters the OTP:Fetch the OTP and timestamp from the email_verification table for that user's email.If the timestamp is too old (say, more than 10 minutes), reject the verification.If the user clicked a magic link, compare the OTP in the magic link with the OTP from the database. If they match, the verification is successful.If the user entered a code manually, compare the entered OTP with the OTP from the database. If they match, the verification is successful.After successful verification, you should delete the OTP entry from the email_verification table to avoid reusing it.On User Requesting a New OTP: When the user asks for a new OTP/magic link:Generate a new OTP as in step 2.Replace the old OTP and timestamp in the email_verification table with the new OTP and current timestamp.This way, you're not storing the OTP in a cookie or a URL, you're keeping the database as the single source of truth, and you're maintaining a secure, user-friendly authentication workflow.

Conversation.Prompt: It's possible I'll want to use this process for more than just email verification. What issues do you foresee with me making this database table more generic? So instead of "email" we'd use more generic terms?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTMaking your database table more generic shouldn't be an issue and could allow for more flexibility in handling different kinds of verification scenarios. This approach will make your authentication system more extensible, so that it can cover different verification needs beyond just email verification.For instance, instead of having a field named "email", you could have a field named "identifier", which could store either an email address, a phone number, or some other unique identifier depending on the use case. You might have another field named "type" to indicate the type of verification being performed (e.g., 'email', 'phone', 'two-factor', etc.).Here's a rough example of how you could structure your table:id: A unique ID for each entryuser_id: The ID of the user this entry belongs toidentifier: The value to be verified (e.g., email, phone number)type: The type of verification (e.g., 'email', 'phone', 'two-factor')secret_key: The secret key used to generate the OTPotp: The generated OTPgeneration_time: The timestamp when the OTP was generatedWith this structure, you should be able to handle a variety of verification scenarios. However, keep in mind that different types of verification may have different security considerations or best practices, so you should review and potentially adjust your security measures for each new type of verification you add.

Is the type field necessary? I think it would be safe to remove this. I think I would like to do that so I don't have to have an additional relational table. Can we remove that?

With expiration_time, you have a straightforward way to determine when a OTP is no longer valid and when it's safe to delete an entry from the table.Now, using Prisma, here's how you might define your schema:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this schema, each Verification is linked to a User. Conversation.Prompt: Would it be reasonable for me to disassociate the verification model from the user? In the case of registration, I don't have a user yet. I'm thinking for registration I could just lookup the verification by the otp which would then allow me to create a new user by the identifier (which would be the email). Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, it's reasonable to disassociate the Verification model from the User if you want to use it for situations like registration where you don't have a user yet. However, you may want to consider how you'll handle the situation where a user is created, but not yet verified. This is where having a relationship between User and Verification could be helpful.In your suggested scenario, you would generate an OTP and email it to the user during the registration process, then, when the user verifies their email, you would look up the Verification entry by the OTP, retrieve the identifier (email), and create a new user with that email.Here's how your models might look in Prisma with the relationship removed:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Please keep in mind, with this approach, there are a few potential issues you'll need to handle:If a user initiates the registration process multiple times with the same email before verifying, you'll need to handle the possibility of multiple Verification entries for the same email.You'll need to handle cleanup of Verification entries once they're no longer needed.If you later want to add a feature that requires knowing which User a Verification is associated with (such as two-factor authentication), you may need to re-introduce the relationship between the two models.So while it does give you the flexibility to handle registration in the manner you described, it might complicate some future developments and add a bit of overhead for handling the above cases. But overall, it should not limit the usefulness of the model in a significant way.

Since it could represent either an email or a user ID depending on the context, you might consider using a term like "verificationValue" or "verificationTarget" to be a bit more descriptive.Here's an updated schema:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In your application code, you can then enforce that the type field must be one of a specific set of allowed values (e.g., 'EMAIL', 'USER_ID').Keep in mind that you should still ensure the verificationTarget and type combination is unique. Conversation.Prompt:
Would that `@@unique` directive work if I used `upsert` when creating verification codes for which one of that type already exists?

Also, if I wanted to use a table for the `type` instead of a string, how would I do that?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT@@unique in Prisma:The @@unique directive in Prisma does not directly interact with upsert. @@unique enforces that the combination of fields it's applied to must be unique in the database.When using upsert (update or insert), if a matching record already exists in the database (i.e., the same verificationTarget and type), Prisma will try to update that record. If no matching record exists, it will insert a new one.However, if a matching record exists but the update would violate the unique constraint (for example, if you're trying to change the verificationTarget or type to a combination that already exists for another record), you would get an error because the unique constraint is violated. So, in other words, upsert cannot be used to bypass the unique constraint.Using a separate table for type:You can certainly use a separate table for type if you'd like. This would allow you to add, remove, or modify verification types without needing to change your code. Here's an example of how you might structure this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this setup, each Verification has a typeId which references an entry in the VerificationType table. The type field in VerificationType would hold the name of each verification type (like 'EMAIL', 'USER_ID'). The unique constraint is now on verificationTarget and typeId instead of verificationTarget and type.

ListOfCode.Content:
model Verification {
  id               Int      @id @default(autoincrement())
  verificationTarget String
  secretKey         String
  otp               String   @unique
  expirationTime    DateTime
  typeId            Int

  type              VerificationType @relation(fields: [typeId], references: [id])

  @@unique([verificationTarget, typeId])
}

model VerificationType {
  id            Int            @id @default(autoincrement())
  type          String         @unique
  verifications Verification[]
}

Conversation.Prompt: What are the drawbacks of having more than one combination of verificationTarget and type?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you have more than one combination of verificationTarget and type, it means you have multiple verification records for the same target. This could cause several potential issues:Confusion for users: If a user receives multiple emails with different verification codes, they might not know which one to use. This could lead to a poor user experience.Potential for misuse: If there are multiple active verifications for the same target, a malicious actor could potentially exploit this to try and verify an email address or account that doesn't belong to them.Increased system complexity: Managing multiple verifications for the same target increases the complexity of your system. You would need to decide how to handle cases where multiple verifications exist: Should the old one be invalidated when a new one is created? Should all be valid until used or expired? These additional edge cases could make your code more complex and difficult to maintain.Performance impact: If you have a large number of redundant verification records, it could increase the size of your database and potentially impact performance. This would be more of a concern for very large systems, but it's still worth considering.For these reasons, it's usually a good idea to enforce uniqueness for the combination of verificationTarget and type. This ensures that for any given type of verification, a particular target can only have one active verification at a time.

Conversation.Prompt: Ok, sounds good. I'm satisfied with the model and the architecture we've discussed. I'm considering whether I should include this model in my application database or if I should create a separate database for this. I'm using SQLite for all my databases and I already have a separate one for caching, so adding another one for verification doesn't feel like a big issue, particularly since the model is so simple so I wouldn't actually need prisma to manage it. Please argue both sides of this decision and make a recommendation.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTAdding the verification model to your existing application database versus creating a new, separate database for it presents a trade-off between simplicity and isolation. Both approaches have their benefits and drawbacks.Including in the existing application database:Benefits:Simplicity: Having your verification model in the same database as the rest of your application data can simplify your architecture. You won't need to maintain a separate connection to a different database for the sole purpose of managing verification records.Consistency: By keeping all data in one place, you can take advantage of database transactions to ensure data consistency.
